summary:
The Security Council,

Adopted resolution 2369 (2017) at its 8014th meeting, on 27 July 2017.

Welcoming the Secretary-General's report (S/2017/586) on the UN operation in Cyprus,

Noting the Government of Cyprus's agreement to extend the UN Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP) beyond 31 July 2017,

Noting the Secretary-General's intention to report on his Good Offices, echoing his belief that the Cypriots themselves are responsible for finding a solution, and reaffirming the UN's primary role in assisting the parties,

Welcoming the 2 April 2017 Joint Statement by the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders, and progress in negotiations, including the Conference on Cyprus in June 2017,

Recalling the international community's emphasis on full, flexible, and constructive engagement in negotiations for a settlement, and encouraging the sides to sustain their commitment,

Noting the need for military confidence-building measures, and urging renewed efforts to implement remaining measures,

Reaffirming the importance of Green Line crossings, and encouraging the opening of other crossing points,

Convinced of the benefits of a comprehensive and durable Cyprus settlement, urging the two sides to foster positive public rhetoric, and encouraging them to explain the benefits of a settlement,

Highlighting the importance of the international community's supporting role, and urging all parties to take practical steps to help the leaders sustain their commitment,

Recalling the Secretary-General's firm belief that the buffer zone situation would improve if both sides accepted the 1989 aide-memoire,

Noting with regret the withholding of access to remaining minefields, and urging rapid agreement on demining operations,

Commending the Committee on Missing Persons, and urging the opening of access to all areas to facilitate its work,

Agreeing that active civil society participation is essential to the political process,

Stressing the need for a rigorous, strategic approach to peacekeeping deployments, and recognizing the need for regular reviews of peacekeeping operations, including UNFICYP.
Here is a concise summary of the Security Council document:

The Security Council:

Appreciates efforts of the Secretary-General, Special Representative Elizabeth Spehar, and Special Adviser Espen Barth Eide.

Welcomes progress in leaders-led process since 11 February 2014 and encourages sustained commitment to a settlement under UN auspices.

Takes note of the Secretary-General's report (S/2017/586) and reaffirms relevant resolutions on Cyprus, particularly resolution 1251 (1999).

Calls on leaders to:

* Work on convergences on core issues
* Continue working with Technical Committees to improve daily lives of Cypriots
* Improve public atmosphere for negotiation
* Increase civil society participation

Requests the Secretary-General to maintain transition planning and encourages engagement between sides, UNFICYP, and the UN Good Offices mission.

Urges implementation of confidence-building measures, including military measures and opening of crossing points.

Welcomes efforts to accommodate the Committee on Missing Persons' requirements and calls for full access to all areas.

Expresses full support for UNFICYP and extends its mandate until 31 January 2018.

Calls on both sides to:

* Engage in consultations on buffer zone demarcation and the 1989 aide-memoire
* Restore military status quo in Strovilia
* Allow access to deminers and facilitate mine removal

Requests a strategic review of UNFICYP and a report on its results.

Expresses full support for the Secretary-General's Good Offices and requests a report on implementation by 10 January 2018.

Welcomes efforts to implement the Secretary-General's zero-tolerance policy on sexual exploitation and abuse.

Decides to remain seized of the matter.
